title: Liverpool given green light to sign new kit deal with Nike after winning New Balance high court challenge
text:
Liverpool have been given the go-ahead to sign a lucrative new kit deal with Nike after winning a high court challenge about their plans to ditch current suppliers New Balance.

The Merseyside club completed negotiations on a five-year contract with Nike last summer but were forced to prove it did not break the terms of its existing relationship.

New Balance, who pay Liverpool £45 million a year in an arrangement ending in summer 2020, inserted a matching clause as part of that agreement.

It entitled them to renew on the basis they could equal a rivals’ offer and argued they had the capacity to do so.

Such is the restructuring of Liverpool’s terms, the deal with Nike guarantees a yearly sum of £30m, which is significantly less than New Balance.

But the Merseyside club argued the incremental rewards will dwarf previous kit supplying contracts because of the vast supply chain on offer, broader distribution and sales potential.

Liverpool also wants to join forces with a brand which is home to a greater portfolio of sporting superstars across the world. In real terms, over the course of their contract Liverpool’s deal with Nike will be worth far more than the £45m a year they currently receive.
